title: Can matter exist without time? - Quora

response.answer_text: If there were zero matter, time probably would have no meaning, so we could say in the total absence of matter, there would be no time. If there were only one proton, say, again, nothing could change, so again time would have no meaning. But when you have two particles, you can always define a velocity of one in the frame of reference of the other (even though it is zero). If you have a velocity, you must have time. So whenever you have more than one fundamental particle, you must have time.

Yes, matter can exist without time. Matter consists of groupings of particles. Energy consists of postulated particles in space. Space is a viewpoint of dimension. The viewpoint considers there is something there; that’s why there is. Time is the consideration that space and particles will persist. But the viewpoint? Ah! There is the fun! Can the viewpoint exist without time? And what is meant by viewpoint? Ask and it is updated.

Time is not a fabrication of matter. Time is a fabrication of life. Inanimate matter has no memory. Time is meaningless without memory. By using the word “exist” you are imposing a human concept of time onto the question. So that means that your question itself is inconsistent and thus meaningless. Cheers.
